The town of Huddersfield lies among hills, moorland and 300 million year outdated river valleys carved out by ancient tropical river deltas and glaciers. Historical past
Huddersfield gets a mention while in the Doomsday book (Oderesfelt). The hill is an critical historical concentrate for Huddersfield. The Saxons had a royal court in Almondbury and inside the reign of King Stephen a castle was created there (hence Castle Hill) but this was demolished inside the 14th century. The hill has the standing of Scheduled Ancient Monument and from its summit can be gained fine views in the surrounding countryside.

Architecture
Huddersfield is renowned for each the number and top quality of its listed buildings and has some truly outstanding examples of Georgian and Victorian architecture. Its railway fa�ade continues to be described by architectural historian Nicolas Pevsner as the greatest neoclassical station fa�ade in Europe�. At Horbury, some 9 miles outdoors Huddersfield lies the 18th century church of St Peter and St Leonard recognised as becoming the finest Georgian church in West Yorkshire.

Even several of the town's much more modern day and controversial buildings have their followers: Adrian Evans, Architect and lecturer at Leeds Metropolitan University believes the present day Market place Hall, constructed inside the late 1960's, to be at least as important architecturally as the station. Be warned even though, other folks have called it plain, shabby and unexciting.

Industrial Heritage
The industrial revolution initiated Huddersfield's transformation right into a textile powerhouse, and that Georgian and Victorian legacy is still Patrick Kane Jersey really evident nowadays in the buildings, canals and old workings that make the town this kind of a valuable historical resource. The Colne Valley Museum in Golcar, just outside Huddersfield is worth a visit to have a flavour of what daily life was like while in the early Victorian, industrial heartlands of Northern Britain.

A single industrial heritage must-see during your remain in Huddersfield may be the 18/19th century Standedge canal tunnel close to Marsden, some 7 miles outside the town centre. This tunnel, finished by Thomas Telford in 1811, may be the highest (645 feet over sea degree), deepest (638 feet under the surface) and longest (3 along with a quarter miles) canal tunnel inside the country. At Overton, some 7 miles outside Huddersfield, you are able to check out the National Coal Mining Museum, created across the former Caphouse Colliery which closed in 1985 and was superbly restored with heritage funding.
